{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3418910,"name":"avi","username":"mar56vel","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/b77776/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-08-28T22:11:50.415Z","cooked":"

hello,
i’m the head of mechanics in my group this year and i feel like i lack a lot of skills i should have and i don’t really know how to fix it.
so, i know how to use almost every machine that we have at a very good level (including lathe , miller and cnc) i never had a problem with learning to use the machines or building in general.

my problem is with mechanical design - to put it simply i’m not very good at it. Whenever I try to think of a solution, it’s usually overly complex, weird, and all around not very good.
i also have trouble with with things like transmission, using motors , etc - overall just how to think and design a good functional mechanism.
trying to research by myself has only been really confusing, and mostly unhelpful.

Unfortunately, most of our mechanical mentors just quit so i can’t ask for help from them, i just feel a bit stuck - i really want to improve on this, but i have no idea how.

im sorry this is long, if anyone has any advice/solution i would really appreciate it.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2024-08-29T02:08:40.216Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":304,"readers_count":303,"score":60.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":470420,"topic_slug":"improving-mechanical-design-skills","display_username":"Zach","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":33848,"username":"jedgar6","name":"jedgar6","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jedgar6/{size}/200602_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":58913,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4415 Leader"},"post_url":"/t/improving-mechanical-design-skills/470420/6","custom_user_title":"4415 Leader","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3419468,"name":"Pizzatc","username":"Pizzatc","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/pizzatc/{size}/207342_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-30T16:02:36.240Z","cooked":"

Learning Mechanical Design and learning how to CAD, in my opinion are two separate things.

Learning how to CAD is easy once you figure out how the tool bar and how constraints operate than you can pretty much design anything you can think of

Learning Mechanical Design is hard and it requires a complex understanding of engineering concepts like forces, torque, tolerances, etc. And then understanding how to apply those to a CAD model can be challenging for some people.

It’s a long process of trial and error and you may work on 10 projects and if you’re lucky 1 project will come into existence but through that experience you will learn.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2024-08-30T16:03:58.303Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":230,"readers_count":229,"score":86.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":470420,"topic_slug":"improving-mechanical-design-skills","display_username":"Pizzatc","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":54022,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2659"},"post_url":"/t/improving-mechanical-design-skills/470420/7","custom_user_title":"2659","reactions":[{"id":"100","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3419489,"name":"tkchan","username":"tkchan","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/t/ee59a6/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-08-30T17:22:17.091Z","cooked":"

Like to add that to be a effective designer, one also has to understands how it will be manufactured. This takes into accounts the resources available (machine, personnel, skills, materials/$, etc).

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2024-08-30T17:22:17.091Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":205,"readers_count":204,"score":101.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":470420,"topic_slug":"improving-mechanical-design-skills","display_username":"tkchan","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":54022,"username":"Pizzatc","name":"Pizzatc","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/pizzatc/{size}/207342_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":26389,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"think outside of the box from time to time"},"post_url":"/t/improving-mechanical-design-skills/470420/8","custom_user_title":"think outside of the box from time to time","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3419502,"name":"AgentSmith451","username":"AgentSmith451","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/agentsmith451/{size}/231133_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-30T18:13:57.560Z","cooked":"
mar56vel:

it’s usually overly complex

This usually comes from diving in too fast. You think about part of a solution (ex: a part that you know how to machine) and shoehorn that into the mechanism. Then because that wasn’t the best, you have to make this other complicated thing to account for this and then that… and so on.

It helps to take a step back and do some low-level prototyping. Pencil and paper, cardboard and a game piece, things like that. Say you’re making an intake. Don’t start with “oh I can make this lever that flips out with wheels and gears and and…”

Start with “the game piece has to get from point A to point B”. Figure out what general path it has to travel. List out options for each part and think about what makes that a good or bad idea. Generally, the fewer moving pieces the better.

For figuring out “is this motor strong enough to do X?” sites like this are a wealth of info. Posting here or even just Googling similar mechanisms with “FRC” in the search will bring up hundreds of photos you can use for reference to get ideas.

You can do it!

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2024-08-30T18:13:57.560Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":178,"readers_count":177,"score":55.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":470420,"topic_slug":"improving-mechanical-design-skills","display_username":"AgentSmith451","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":31049,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor - Team 451 "The Cat Attack""},"post_url":"/t/improving-mechanical-design-skills/470420/9","custom_user_title":"Mentor - Team 451 "The Cat Attack"","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3419525,"name":"tkchan","username":"tkchan","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/t/ee59a6/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-08-30T19:12:12.150Z","cooked":"

Good points, I also always remind our students…don’t fall in love with your 1st idea during the early-prototyping stage. Keep an open mind, keep trying different alternatives and most importantly the KISS principle.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2024-08-30T19:12:12.150Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":150,"readers_count":149,"score":30.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":470420,"topic_slug":"improving-mechanical-design-skills","display_username":"tkchan","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":31049,"username":"AgentSmith451","name":"AgentSmith451","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/agentsmith451/{size}/231133_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":26389,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"think outside of the box from time to time"},"post_url":"/t/improving-mechanical-design-skills/470420/10","custom_user_title":"think outside of the box from time to time","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3419548,"name":"Jim Sokoloff","username":"sokoloff","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sokoloff/{size}/231724_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-30T20:58:00.773Z","cooked":"

Linus Pauling:
“The best way to have a good idea is to have lots of ideas.”

Beyond just having a lot of ideas, having a way to tell bad ideas from good ones is important and that’s the role of testing and prototyping. Fortunately, the FRC game structure usually gives a way to get good feedback on that point. (Heavy agreement with @tkchan above.)

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2024-08-30T20:58:00.773Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":143,"readers_count":142,"score":28.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":470420,"topic_slug":"improving-mechanical-design-skills","display_username":"Jim Sokoloff","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":66298,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"97 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/improving-mechanical-design-skills/470420/11","custom_user_title":"97 Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3419747,"name":"avi","username":"mar56vel","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/b77776/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-08-31T18:56:26.394Z","cooked":"

my main problem is that i can’t really do projects with the state of my team right now - so i’m trying to find ways to improve without doing that.
i was planning on doing projects ( and definitely will when i can) but for now i was wondering if there’s other things i can do to improve?

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2024-08-31T18:56:26.394Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":118,"readers_count":117,"score":23.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":470420,"topic_slug":"improving-mechanical-design-skills","display_username":"avi","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":54022,"username":"Pizzatc","name":"Pizzatc","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/pizzatc/{size}/207342_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60010,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/improving-mechanical-design-skills/470420/12","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3419822,"name":"Brendan Conover","username":"bcon","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bcon/{size}/169080_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-31T22:06:45.957Z","cooked":"

@mar56vel

Introducing FRCDesign.org - High-quality FRC design knowledge, accessible to all CAD
[image] Learning design should be easy. If you are a beginner, learning robot design and CAD sucks. You went through some beginner CAD courses, and watched a video series or two, and by the end, you still have no clue how to start designing an FRC robot. If you are self-taught, you might spend dozens of hours on something that might take someone else an hour or two, and you have no clue why. We had four goals. Access: Nobody should have to reinvent the wheel. Make high-quality design and CAD…
